question: 12 (i)
sols_html:
The answer is false.

Let \(v_1 = \begin{pmatrix} 1\\1\\1\end{pmatrix}, v_2 = \begin{pmatrix} 1\\0\\1\end{pmatrix},\) and \(v_3 = \begin{pmatrix} 2\\1\\3\end{pmatrix}\) denote the given vectors.

A matrix A has eigenvectors \(v_1, v_2, v_3\) with corresponding respective eigenvalues 1, -1, 4 if and only if \(A = P\Lambda P^{-1}\), where

\(P = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 & 2\\ 1& 0 &1\\ 1 & 1 & 3 \end{pmatrix}\) and \(\Lambda = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0\\ 0& -1 &0\\ 0 & 0 & 4 \end{pmatrix}.\)

Thus the matrix A exists if and only if P is invertible (that is, if and only if \(v_1, v_2, v_3\) are linearly independent).

We can calculate \(\det P= 1 \neq 0\). Therefore, P is invertible and the desired matrix A will be given by \(A = P \Lambda P^{-1}\).

Remark: By computing the inverse (not necessary to answer the question), we can determine the explicit form of A as

\(A = \begin{pmatrix} -9 & 2 & 8\\ -3& 1 &3\\ -13 & 2 & 12 \end{pmatrix}.\)
